bibl.title: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 26, 1927

div1.p: Russell writes about current work on yellow fever, mentioning Dunn, Klotz, Beeuwkes, Noguchi and Carter. He discusses Carter's belief that yellow fever came to the Americas with slaves from West Africa.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 26, 1927

CABLE ADDRESS “ROCKFOUND”
October 25, 1927.
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
Your letter of October 24th has just arrived.
Next time I go down to Washington I will try to see you to
talk over the history of Reed's work in yellow fever.

I doubt if just now is the proper time for me to
write anything about the present work on yellow fever be-
cause we are at a critical point in our studies. The next
year or two will, undoubtedly, clear up any questions that
are still unsettled. Beeuwkes has a good group of men in
Lagos, Nigeria, West Africa. They are doing a fine piece
of work and the results of their studies will be published
from time to time as they become available. The following
articles by Mr. Lawrence H. Dunn and Professor Oskar Klotz
will be published very shortly:
“Mosquito Breeding in Crab Holes” by L. H. Dunn

“Tree holes and Mosquito Breeding
in West Africa” by " " "

"Further observations on Mosquito
Breeding in Tree Holes by " " "

“Observations on the Oviposition
of Aedes aegypti, Linn., in
relation to distance from
Habitations.” by " " "

"Mosquito Breeding in “Test”
Water Containers by " " "
General Jefferson R. Kean
October 25, 1927

These papers will be published in the Bulletin of Entomological
Research.

“Mosquitoes bred from dry material
taken from holes in trees” by L.H. Dunn
has already been published in the Bulletin of Entomological
Research.

“The Spleen in West African Yellow
Fever” by Oskar Klotz
will be published in the American Journal of Pathology.

“Jaundice and the Liver Lesions in
West African Yellow Fever” by Oskar Klotz
will be published in the American Journal of Tropical Medicine.

Beeuwkes reports that they have been able to produce
yellow fever in Asiatic monkeys, best in Maccacus rhesus, and
that they have transmitted it both by inoculation of blood
from yellow fever cases from monkey to monkey, and also by
mosquitoes from money to monkey; also by stegomyia from mon-
key to monkey. This is confidential. Beeuwkes will soon
have papers for publication.

Noguchi sailed yesterday for Lagos to study the question
of Leptospira icteroides in West African yellow fever. The men
we have previously sent over have been unable to find it. It
remains now to be seen what Noguchi himself will find there.

Dr. Henry R. Carter before his death had almost comple-
ted a history on yellow fever which will, I hope, soon be ready
General Jefferson R. Kean
-3-
October 25, 1927
for publication. In it there are many things of interest,
one of which is that Carter convinced himself that yellow
fever came to the Americas with the slaves from West Africa,
and that it was distributed around the West Indies and to the
mainland by the buccaneers.

We are arranging our studies so as to show if it is
possible to do so, the relationship of West African to American
yellow fever. The pathological work has been completed and
it shows no difference between the two hemispheres, but much
remains to be done before one can draw conclusions.

You will easily see from what I have said that a year
from now will be a much better time to bring up the question
than the present moment.
With best wishes, I am
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, F F Russell General Jefferson R. Kean, Editor
“The Military Surgeon”
Army Medical Museum
Seventh and B Streets SW
Washington, D.C.
